learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate understanding of how creative content behaves in different media contexts and adapts to different understandings of user engagement.
Work effectively in creative teams to pitch a multimedia storyworld in the form of a formal presentation involving all team members.
Produce original media assets that showcase a transmedia storyworld, drawing on practices such as photography, graphic design, illustration, and audio-visual production.
Critically explain and justify creative decisions in a media portfolio through application of transmedia concepts and relevant theoretical ideas covered in the course.

assessments.task_description:
Students should attend two individual in-class consultations with their tutor scheduled during the semester. Assessment 1 part A is scheduled before the midterm break, and Assessment 1 part B is scheduled in the second half of the course.  

These consultations are centred around the students’ portfolio work (submitted to Blackboard before the consultations). Students will explain and justify their creative and technical decisions, demonstrating critical analysis skills developed in the course, by using concepts and vocabulary pertinent to transmedia storytelling. 


The Assessment 1 has 2 components:  

  • Portfolio entry:  
  • Submission of portfolio process to Blackboard BEFORE class. This can be notes, sketches, drawings, mindmaps, storyboards or any other format that shows your thinking process towards working to the final portfolio. Assessment 1 Part B must show improvement/progress from what was submitted to Assessment 1 part A. 
  • Consultations:  
  • In-class consultations with the tutor, where students explain their portfolio work.  
  • No notes or machine translation tools can be used during the consultation.  


Full details and a comprehensive grading rubric are provided on Blackboard under "Assessments". 


AI Policy 

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.due_date:
17/04/2026 4:00 pm

Portfolio and Statement: Due date listed above.
assessments.task_description:
You will work in a creative team (3 to 5 students) to create a transmedia storyworld that exists authentically across multiple platforms. Each team member is responsible for one platform/medium, ensuring that the story elements respond and capitalise on each medium’s unique features (medium specificity).  

Assessment components (both to be submitted individually on Blackboard):  

  1. Media portfolio
  2. Statement explaining your submission


1 Portfolio: Each person in the team must produce a media portfolio of creative and original work using the Adobe Suite flagship programs (Photoshop, Premiere Pro, Audition, Illustrator, InDesign). We want you to use these software because they are the industry standard. At this point, we are interested in your plans, no polished work is expected for this assessment.

You can use a variety of different formats, such as drawing and illustration, still photography, posters, audio-visual material, including video or music, among others. We are open to your ideas! 

Examples of adequately substantial individual media portfolio submitted at the mid-semester stage will be shown and discussed in tutorials and lectures. 

Original content only:  

  • No stock images or footage (except scoring/music).  
  • Only content produced during the period of this course (no old pictures/footage). 


Process Evidence Requirement: You must provide clear evidence of your creative and technical process, such as: 

  • Screenshots of Adobe timelines/layers 
  • Drafts, early exports, failed tests 
  • Original assets files 
  • Version history 
  • Prompt logs (if AI/MT was used).  
  • This evidence supports secure assessment and authorship verification. We want to see that you have used the Adobe Creative suite with minimal to no use of AI tools. 


2 Statement: With your media portfolio, you must submit a written statement explaining your submission. Students must answer the following questions: 

  • What is your team storyworld about? How is your media output contributing to your team storyworld?
  • How did you create this work? How was the Adobe Suite used? 
  • How are you capitalising on medium specificity? 
  • Demonstrate how the course’s ideas have informed your work.  
  • Did you use AI or Machine Translation tools at any stage? If yes, specify which tools, how, and why, and what parts of the work are fully your own and what parts are AI generated. Was it helpful? How? Justify the use of these tools.  


Full details and a comprehensive grading rubric are provided on Blackboard under "Assessments". 


AI Policy 

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Portfolio and Statement: Submitted via Blackboard. Large files should be submitted as links to online folders (like OneDrive) or online platforms (like YouTube). Each person is responsible for submitting their own materials that they want marked on Blackboard.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date:
29/05/2026 4:00 pm

Pitch: In Week 13 tutorials.

Portfolio and Statements: Due date listed above.
assessments.task_description:
For this task, students will continue working in the same creative teams. Assessment 3 has four components, each marked individually: 

  1. Pitch/Presentation: Presented in class to your peers (2-3 minutes for each person in the group).  
  2. Media portfolio (submitted individually on Blackboard).  
  3. Statement explaining your submission (submitted to Blackboard with the media portfolio). 
  4. Peer Assessment Statement addressing the group dynamics (submitted to Blackboard with the media portfolio).


1 Pitch/Presentation: Students work in the same creative teams assigned for Assessment 2. The team will pitch a transmedia storyworld (either fictional or nonfictional) that exists across as many media platforms as there are people in that group. At this stage, your project must justify how it wants to treat the user/audience and create pathways for audience participation in your storyworld.  

The pitch should mirror professional industry standards and must introduce what your storyworld is about, what your media platform is contributing to the overall idea, what kind of audience you have in mind, what opportunities the audience has for participation, and lastly, what you made and why. 

Each person in the team must present what they created and explain how it connects with the overall team idea. 

All presentations will be recorded for marking purposes via recording facilities available where the assessment takes place (eg. ECHO360, Zoom, camera device)  

Recordings will be retained by the School of Communication and Arts for at least 12 months from the release of the final grade for the course.  

Recordings will be stored in a secure manner and will only be accessed by authorised school staff for the purposes of: 

  • Moderation of marking;  
  • Provision of feedback to the student(s) recorded; and/or  
  • Re-marking following a successful re-mark application. 


2 Portfolio: At this stage, the individual portfolio should demonstrate noticeable improvement from the first submission (Assessment 2), including new media developed since the midterm, pushing your storyworld concept further.  You are expected to work with the Adobe Suite flagship programs (Photoshop, Premiere Pro, Audition, Illustrator, InDesign) in the production of your portfolio.  

Examples of adequately substantial individual final media portfolios will be shown and discussed in tutorials and lectures. 

Original content only:  

  • No stock images or footage (except scoring/music).  
  • Only content produced during the period of this course (no old pictures/footage). 


Process Evidence Requirement: You must provide clear evidence of your creative and technical process, such as: 

  • Screenshots of Adobe timelines/layers 
  • Drafts, early exports, failed tests 
  • Original assets files 
  • Version history 
  • Prompt logs (if AI/MT was used).  
  • This evidence supports secure assessment and authorship verification. We want to see that you have used the Adobe Creative suite with minimal to no use of AI tools. 


3 Statement: A statement that describes the rationale behind the final submission and how it connects to the larger project. The statement should capture the student’s approach to their component of the final project and detail how the project connects to key ideas discussed during this course. Your statement should:  

  • Describe how the Adobe Suite was used in this project, highlighting key issues/opportunities encountered in using these programs.  
  • Justify your creative choices, using the key concepts discussed in this course. Which concepts were most relevant in your work? Explain the “why” behind your creative choices.  
  • Explain how you considered and fostered audience participation. 
  • Did you use AI or Machine Translation tools at any stage? If yes, specify which tools, how, and why, and what parts of the work are fully your own and what parts are AI generated. Was it helpful? How? Justify the use of these tools.  


4 Peer Assessment Statement: A statement addressing the group dynamics: 

  • How was the work divided within your team, and did this approach work well? 
  • Were there any issues with collaboration, and if so, how were they managed? 
  • What were your individual responsibilities, and how did you contribute? 
  • Did you need to complete any tasks assigned to others? 
  • What challenges did you face, and what might you do differently next time? 


Full details and a comprehensive grading rubric are provided on Blackboard under "Assessments". 


AI Policy 

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Pitch/Presentation: Will take place during the Week 13 tutorial. Missing the group pitch without communicating with tutors beforehand and without an appropriate reason will result in an automatic fail for your group component. Please note that vacations or other work commitments are not acceptable excuses for missing this presentation date.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.
